children.subject: If that does apply to you, then yeah, I believe all you have to do is complete all the assignments in the relevant section of the course. You'll probably have to work out the specifics with the instructor.

Somewhat unrelated question: Is CS 47A/CS 47B intended for people who have, for example, completed a course like CS 88 which has a 50%+ overlap with CS 61A?

Can the 47 classes be used for declaring Letters and Sciences CS?

>Can the 47 classes be used for declaring Letters and Sciences CS?

Yes. But they count differently when calculate the 3.3 GPA needed to declare.

>Is CS 47A/CS 47B intended for people who have, for example, completed a course like CS 88 which has a 50%+ overlap with CS 61A?

If you have any prior exposure to the material, like transfer, upper division or graduate course work, you can ask the CS 61x professors to let you in their CS 47x connector course instead. The professor made that decision on a case-by-cases basis. Sometime people who took 61B can take 47A instead of 61A.
I don't think you can take CS 47 classes directly. CS 47C is only for students who have partially completed 61C and need to finish part of the class.

history.content:
Anon. Beaker is correct. The bridge courses (47A-E) are for students who have taken courses that teach a substantial portion of the material in 61ABC, 70 and 16AB, respectively. The instructors for the regular course can decide whether you can take the bridge course, based on what you took previously.

Anon. Calc, for questions about how to use CS 88 toward completing 61A, send an e-mail to cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu since there is a general policy about this. If you're using a 47A or B to declare, it will only factor in for the number of units you took it for (usually 1 unit, rather than 4 units for 61A or 61B).

Once the faculty member agrees, one of the advising staff will usually give you a code to get into the bridge course unless the faculty themselves do.

Is CS47C (self pace for 61C) structured similarly like 47B? (Where you only do the projects and quizzes)? I wasn't able to find a course website for this.

Thank you!
history.subject: Content in 47C?
